title: Ticket #3073: RFE: chirp in local universe
description:
+WantIOProxy (chirp) is not available for jobs running in the local universe.

chirp provides both remote file IO and job ad attribute operations.

The attribute operations are important in this situation. Remote file IO in local universe is less important (job is not remote).

FYI, local universe has the schedd running a starter directly, there is no shadow in play.

FYI, chirp fails with: Can't open /var/lib/condor/spool/local_univ_execute/dir_5021/chirp.config file cannot chirp_connect to shadow

Attached a patch to add chirp to local U. All vanilla functionality exists including I/O. Flow is chirp->local_io_proxy_handler->jobupdater for attr related. I/O is handled in the new local_io_proxy_handler object much like it is in NTReceivers/pseudo_ops in vanilla chirp.

On a side note, there are two bugs in chirp not related to this: 1) 3542 and 2) write has a bug on the condor_chirp side where swrite isn't even being used and there is no way to perform some types of simple writes.

2013-May-07 18:15:51 by eje:
I'm concerned about the massive parallel code paths IOProxyHandler::handle_standard_request() and LocalIOProxyHandler::handle_standard_request(). That will double the dev/testing effort for any future changes to chirp commands, and just as likely become a bug factory when they drift out of sync.

It would be worth some effort to figure out how to unify REMOTE_CONDOR_xxx() with xxx(), so we can keep handle_standard_request() unified.

2013-May-08 08:09:03 by jrt:
Either you have one large parallel code path where the difference between local and vanilla is clear from the very beginning when the ioproxy object is created or you put if (vanilla).. in 22 functions. I think it's mostly a matter of choice although as I recall there are some visibility issues with putting everything in NTsenders.

I'll take a look to see if moving the code is workable.
